Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Algorithms and Models for Distributed Computation of Bayesian Phylogenetics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Given a set of molecular (DNA, RNA, or amino acid) sequences obtained from a number of organisms, phylogenetic inference is the task of reconstructing the evolutionary relationships among the sequences. These relationships are represented as an evolutionary tree, or, more generally, a directed, acyclic graph (DAG) when horizontal or vertical transmission of genetic material is modeled. The proposed project investigates the popular Bayesian approach to phylogenetic inference. Currently, all popular software packages for Bayesian inference utilize Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms. The problem is that these algorithms can take months to converge on large inference problems.The project's aim is to develop parallel algorithms for MCMC that are suitable for use in a modern cluster compute environment, such as Amazon.com's EC2 service. To ensure broader impacts of this work, the software, along with a user's manual and tutorial, will be open-sourced and the PIs will make special effort in recruiting students from underrepresented groups

For a phylogenetic inference algorithm to scale to thousands of organisms, parallelization is mandatory. For example, one idea that the project will expore is the so-called Bayesian Forest (BF) approach. In the BF approach, the MCMC algorithm maintains not one tree or DAG, but dozens, hundreds, or thousands of trees or DAGs at the same time, where all of them work together and share information with one another as the algorithm runs. This tends to avoid problems associated with converging to poor, locally optimal solutions because as long as one tree/DAG has avoided a problem configuration, over time, that tree/DAG can pull the entire forest away from the poor solution. Crucially, since the most expensive computations over the individual trees/DAGs are independent of one another, it is easy to send them to different machines. The project will also consider distributed algorithms for challenging variants of the problem, such as multi-loci data sets and vertical and horizontal transmission of genetic material, as well as co-estimation of gene and species trees. All software, along with a user's manual and tutorial, will be open-sourced. The project web page will be available at http://cmj4.web.rice.edu/phylogenetics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at developing novel models and computational techniques to speed up Bayesian inference of phylogenies. The phylogenies could be trees or networks. Network inferene is particularly challenging, and arises in cases when the evolutionary history of the taxa under consideration is not strictly treelike. The methods we develop can handle data from a single locus (e.g., sequence alignment from one gene) or multiple loci (as is typically the case in phylogenomic analyses). The project resulted in several technical results that have advanced the field and that would serve as the basis for further developments in the future. In particular, the project pursued two directions to accomplish the goals:

  1. Developing new models and techniques for aspects of phylogenetic inference that had not been done before. 
  2. Exploring systems approaches, in particular database approaches, to large-scale statistical inference. 

For the first direction, the project developed new models of multi-locus phylogenetic network inference from sequence alignment and bi-allelic marker data. To speed up likelihood calculations under these models, the project also introduced pseudo-likelihood functions as well as techniques for integrating out the continuous parameters of these structures. Most importantly for this direction, the project resulted in the first divide-and-conquer technique for phylogenetic network inference using sub-networks estimated by Bayesian inference, along with their parameters and uncertainty measures. This divide-and-conquer method allows for distributed computing to be applied to the problem as the collection of sub-networks can be inferred in a parallel/distributed manner. 

For the second direction, we developed a number of algorithms and computer systems techniques for large-scale and parallel statistical inference.  For example, one of the standard methodologies for phylogenetic network inference is Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC). MCMC is very difficult to effectively parallelize across multiple computers because it requires simulating a Markov chain, which is a sequential process. We developed a new methodology called shepherding distributions, which allows each machine in a compute cluster to simulate a separate Markov chain, subject to a periodic combining step. We showed how this can be used to effectively parallelize MCMC simulation accross multiple machines.

The work has significant impact on evolutionary biology, in particular on phylogenomic analyses. Most of the techniques developed as part of the project have been implemented and made publicly available in the PhyloNet software package. 

Last but not least, the project provided great opportunities for training undergraduate and graduate students. Those students received interdisciplinary training that combined algorithms, systems, statistical inference, and phylogenetics.
